title: Erdős Problem #205: 2^k + m with Few Prime Factors
description: Can all large n be written as 2^k + m where Ω(m) < log log m? DISPROVED by Barreto-Leeham (2026).

overview.historicalContext: Erdős asked whether all large n can be represented as 2^k + m with few prime factors. Related to Romanoff's theorem (1934) on 2^k + prime representations and Erdős's work on covering systems.
overview.problemStatement: Is it true that all sufficiently large n can be written as 2^k + m for some k ≥ 0, where Ω(m) < log log m? Here Ω(m) counts prime divisors with multiplicity.
overview.proofStrategy: The disproof uses a counterexample construction: there exist infinitely many n such that ALL remainders n - 2^k have at least c√(log n / log log n) prime factors, which dominates log log n for large n.
keyInsights: Ω(n) averages to log log n by classical results (Hardy-Ramanujan)
Almost all n DO have such representations (probabilistic argument)
But infinitely many n fail: all their remainders have too many prime factors
The threshold √(log n / log log n) grows faster than log log n
Related to covering systems and 2^k + prime representations

conclusion.summary: Erdős Problem #205 is DISPROVED. Barreto-Leeham (2026) showed there are infinitely many n where every remainder n - 2^k has Ω ≥ c√(log n / log log n) prime factors, which exceeds log log m for large n.
conclusion.implications: Even with the very weak bound Ω(m) < log log m, not all integers can be represented as 2^k + m. This strengthens our understanding of the limitations of power-of-2 representations.
openQuestions: What is the optimal growth rate f(n) such that all large n have representation with Ω(m) < f(n)?
Can the density of exceptions be quantified?
What is the structure of the exceptional n?
